Articles.Content:
Laaaaaaaaag!

I wonder, if there is any activity on Pluto... like geysers or auroras or clouds or ...
So, just to recap, NASA TV coverage of the Phone Home call should start around 2030 (14/7) ET - 0030 (15/7) UT - 0230 (15/7) CE
I'm staying awake.

I'm staying awake.

Me too! Feeling a bit tired after 24 hours of being awake already, but never as much tired and anxious as the NH team right now

Two hours to go, the DSN is uplinking to New Horizons.

Edited July 14, 2015 by Mau

I wish I was smart enough to combine this:

With this...:

"Bring out the gimp.."

Edited July 14, 2015 by Aethon
You do not have a complete dataset, so you will need some intense fiddling/meddling or just plain leave stuff out to get a coherent picture.

I wish I was smart enough to combine this:

With this...:

"Bring out the gimp.."

Luckily, someone has done just that for us.

Luckily, someone has done just that for us.

http://www.unmannedspaceflight.com/index.php?act=attach&type=post&id=36898

That works, as long as people are told that it's false/exaggerated color. Wouldn't want people thinking that was the latest imagery.

That works, as long as people are told that it's false/exaggerated color. Wouldn't want people thinking that was the latest imagery.

True. However I suspect that the NASA images aren't that close to true color either.

True. However I suspect that the NASA images aren't that close to true color either.

NASA's press releases have stated that they are presented "in approximately true color", so it's probably pretty close.
If that is really approximate true colour, Pluto has a lot more going on than just being that inert ice body people took it for.

Seems the "phone home" signal has passed Saturn's orbit. Can't be long now!

Edited July 15, 2015 by Kerbin Dallas Multipass

NASA's press releases have stated that they are presented "in approximately true color", so it's probably pretty close.

Yes, but there has been a lot of discussion (amongst people which know much more photography than I do) on how much green information they can extrapolate from the red and the blue filters. I asked one of the guys on the mission and he replied, "it's as close as possible as we can get to true color", which is not really the answer I wanted because it's not really an answer, but I didn't ask further as I had a lot of other questions on topics I know better and he's a great guy and I didn't want to stress him.
So I am watching NASA TV and they seem to be showing Apollo Soyuz docking stuff. Is there a better channel I should be watching?

Yes, but there has been a lot of discussion (amongst people which know much more photography than I do) on how much green information they can extrapolate from the red and the blue filters. I asked one of the guys on the mission and he replied, "it's as close as possible as we can get to true color", which is not really the answer I wanted because it's not really an answer, but I didn't ask further as I had a lot of other questions on topics I know better and he's a great guy and I didn't want to stress him.

While it is not really an answer, it is probably as much as we need to know. This is what we will get.

So I am watching NASA TV and they seem to be showing Apollo Soyuz docking stuff. Is there a better channel I should be watching?

Right now you mean? Livestream starts in 30 minutes. Plus, I'd love to see an Apollo docking thing!

- - - Updated - - -

While it is not really an answer, it is probably as much as we need to know. This is what we will get.

Absolutely, I'm sorry if I sounded like I was complaining, don't get me wrong, I love Pluto this mission the people behind it and, as you can tell by the fact that on every page of this thread there's an average of 2/3 posts by me you get the idea of how excited I am :D

Right now you mean? Livestream starts in 30 minutes. Plus, I'd love to see an Apollo docking thing!

The Apollo Soyuz Docking is just fine to watch, I just was getting worried that I was going to miss history because of it. Thanks for the information.

Luckily, someone has done just that for us.

Wow Frida, that's beautiful. Analyzing.

Can you link us?

Edited July 15, 2015 by Aethon

...and we're live! www.ustream.tv/nasahdtv

- - - Updated - - -

Can you link us?

Link to what? Sorry I'm not very good at this English language thing!

Hurray, they included Philea in their introductory clip For an organisation that has, at times, been somewhat self centered (or at least US centered), I think that is a wonderful thing to do. Space flight and science both are international endeavours. We are peers and friends. Hello ESA!

Absolutely, I'm sorry if I sounded like I was complaining, don't get me wrong, I love Pluto this mission the people behind it and, as you can tell by the fact that on every page of this thread there's an average of 2/3 posts by me you get the idea of how excited I am :D

You do not sound like you are compaining at all You made a very valid observation about the remark - it indeed does say little about how much it resembles what humans would see - and post a lot of great insights and background information. Please, continue! Your excitement is infectious in the best way possible.

You do not sound like you are compaining at all You made a very valid observation about the remark - it indeed does say little about how much it resembles what humans would see - and post a lot of great insights and background information. Please, continue! Your excitement is infectious in the best way possible.

Hahaha, thank you so much for your kind words!

Ten minutes to go! I don't know how I am sitting still.

Edited July 15, 2015 by Mau

5 minutes! Waiting patiently.

http://eyes.nasa.gov/dsn/dsn.html

I intentionally slept through the livestream of the flyby this morning because I thought it was a bit contrived, but I saw all the hype this morning. What surprises me is that there's so little hype surrounding this imminent data link? For me, this is where the rubber meets the road. Fingers crossed that we receive the signal on schedule and that New Horizons is healthy.
